# Question

Write a function `timezone_bumper(dt,bump)` that increases any provided timestamp by `bump::Int` hours (defaults to +3 hours). Make sure it works only for DateTime types and throws an error for Date types.

Here is the Julia code implementing your requirement:

```julia
using Dates

function timezone_bumper(dt::DateTime, bump=3)
    # Throws an error if a Date type object is passed in instead of DateTime
    if typeof(dt) == Date 
        throw(ArgumentError("The function can only accept DateTime types."))
    end

    return dt + Dates.Hour(bump)
end
```
This function checks the type of the input `dt`. If it is not a `DateTime` type, then an error will be thrown. Otherwise, the time `dt` will be increased by `bump` hours and returned as the result.

Please note that this function does not consider timezone shifts if the bump is applied in different timezone than the input datetime. If you need to handle this case you would have to include some additional logic that takes into account the timezone of the input datetime.
